THE PROPOSAL

II.

INTRODUCTION

The Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh requested the Asian Development
2.
Bank (ADB) to provide a loan to finance a second nonformal education project to be called Post-
Literacy  and  Continuing  Education  Project.  The  Project  is  included  in  ADB’s  country  assistance
plan  as  a  firm  2001  loan.  On  Government’s  request,  ADB  provided  technical  assistance  (TA)1
between January and June 2001 to assist the Government in preparing the Project aimed at poor
neo-literates2 in 29 districts.3 The Project will help to build an effective and sustainable system of
continuing education in the country, and fill a critical gap in the Government’s efforts to sustain the
literacy skills of neo-literates and promoting employable and income-generating skills for the poor.
In  the  past,  ADB  provided  assistance  to  the  Government  under  the  first  Nonformal  Education
Project (NFEP-1)4 to establish the Directorate of Nonformal Education (DNFE) and for giving basic
literacy training to the poor. This Project will build on the investments made through NFEP-1 and
strengthen DNFE in its new role of supervising the implementation of post-literacy and continuing
education (PLCE) by private sector organizations including nongovernment organizations (NGOs).
Throughout  project  preparation,  there  was  close  consultation  with  government  officials  of  the
Primary  and  Mass  Education  Division  (PMED),  DNFE,  NGOs,  envisaged  beneficiaries  at
community level, and education and training providers. All external funding agencies contributing to
the subsector were also consulted closely during Project processing. The project framework is in
Appendix 1.

III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1.

Socioeconomic Context

3.
Bangladesh  is  a  low-income  country,  with  a  per  capita  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  of
$381 in FY2000.  Given the current population size of an estimated 129.3 million and population
growth rate of 1.47 percent per annum, the population grows by about 2 million annually. Although
Bangladesh  has  achieved  a  commendable  average  annual  GDP  growth  rate  of  about  5  percent
during recent years, the poor, especially in rural areas, have derived little or no benefit from such
growth due to great inequality in income levels.

4.
Although  declining,  poverty  remains  widespread.  The  high  poverty  incidence  of  44.7
percent in 1999, compared with 47.0 percent in 1996, indicates that almost 60 million people are

44.9  percent,  whereas  urban  poverty  declined  slightly  from  44.4  percent  to  43.3  percent.    This
trend  is  confirmed  by  other  poverty  indicators,  such  as  the  human  poverty  index  ([HPI]  which

5.
Eighty  percent  of  the  population  live  in  rural  areas  and  over  75  percent  of  the  labor  force
work in agriculture. Agriculture’s share in GDP fell from 36 percent in 1979 to less than 20 percent
in  1999.  Future  increases  in  employment  will  have  to  be  found  increasingly  in  the  nonagriculture

million  over  the  next  20  years  based  on  previous  fertility  levels.  The  number  of  workers  entering
the workforce during the next 10 years will be growing at about 3 percent per year. Employment
will accordingly need to grow in excess of 3 percent to avoid increased levels of underemployment.
With little room for increased agricultural employment, nonfarm employment has to absorb surplus
labor  in  rural  areas  (for  example  in  formal/informal  manufacturing,  trade,  transport,  and
construction).

6.
Education  and  level  of  skills  largely  determine  the  specific  occupational  opportunities  that
the poor can avail themselves of. However, the poor have few educational skills training or skills
enhancement opportunities. This places special demands on the education sector in general and
on  nonformal  education  (NFE)  in  particular.  The  Government's  efforts  to  improve  education  are
reflected  in  increased  education  expenditure  during  the  past  decade,  from  2.2  percent  to  2.75
percent of GDP in FY 2000/01. Poverty reduction through accelerated economic growth is the main
thrust of the Government's medium-term development strategy laid out in the country's current Fifth
Five-Year Plan (1997-2002).6

7.
The  correlation  between  education  and  poverty  is  well  established.  The  Government
promotes NFE as an important means of poverty reduction. Significant investments in basic literacy
programs have resulted in raising the literacy rate from 35 percent in 1990 to about 64 percent in
2000 for people aged 15 and over. Although the female literacy rate still lags behind that of males
(57.0  percent  versus  67.0  percent),  the  impact  of  this  achievement  can  be  seen  across  social
sectors,  most  notably  in  improved  population  life  expectancy  and  lower  fertility  rates.  In  a  recent
pilot  study  that  combined  literacy  development  with  vocational  skills  training,  learners  reported
increased  income  opportunities,  improved  health,  better  hygiene,  and  higher  social  awareness.7
This  suggests  that  focusing  resources  on  literacy  training  combined  with  nonformal  continuing
education can have a strong impact on poverty.

2.

The Formal Education System

8.
The current education system in Bangladesh consists of five years of compulsory primary
education  and  seven  years  of  secondary  education  comprising  three  years  of  junior  secondary
(grades 6-8), two years of secondary (grades 9-10), and two years of higher secondary education
(grades  11-12).  Bangladesh  has  made  considerable  strides  in  providing  access  to  primary
education for all. Enrollments in the country’s 77,000 primary schools have grown rapidly in recent
years  to  reach  a  total  of  over  17.7  million  children,  10.8  million  of  whom  are  in  Government
schools.  Official  data  for  June  2000  show  that  the  gross  primary  enrollment  rate  increased  from
77.0 percent to 97.0 percent over the past decade, while the current net primary enrollment rate is

10.

3.

 Nonformal Education

11.
Unlike many developing countries, Bangladesh has a largely homogeneous population with
a common cultural and linguistic identity. The fact that Bangla is spoken throughout the country is
particularly  advantageous  in  the  spread  of  literacy  and  basic  education.  Reflecting  the
Government’s  commitment  to  promoting  literacy,  there  have  been  significant  improvements  in
access  to  NFE  in  the  last  decade.  Since  the  first  ADB-supported  NFE  project,  the  Government
through  the  DNFE  has  provided  basic  literacy  education  to  17  million  learners,  aged  between  8
and 45, who have not attended school or who dropped out of school. Although there is a problem
of incomplete data about achievements of these projects, available data suggest that between 51

12.
A variety of NFE programs are in use in Bangladesh. The courses are of various duration,
follow  diverse  objectives,  and  are  implemented  by  NGOs  and  by  several  Government  ministries,
often  aided  by  external  assistance  (e.g.,  30,000  children  in  NFE  centers  funded  by  the  United
Nations  Development  Programme  [UNDP],  under  the  Ministry  of  Social  Welfare.  DNFE  is
responsible for all Government-funded basic literacy and post-literacy programs. Most courses last
for  9  months  (6  months  basic  literacy  and  3  months  post-literacy)  or  10  months  (6  months  basic
literacy  and  4  months  post-literacy).  One  project  aimed  at  hard-to-reach  urban  children  provides
courses of 24 months duration. Under all programs, classes take place for two hours each day, six
days a week, and are timed to allow the learners to continue to work.

Many  NGOs  run  NFE  programs  ranging  from  preschool  education  to  skills-based  training
13.
and adult basic education programs. The nonformal primary education program of the Bangladesh
Rural Advancement Committee has an extensive network of close to 40,000 centers serving about
two  million  older  children  who  have  dropped  out  of  primary  school  or  have  never  enrolled.  Other
NGOs  cater  to  the  needs  of  specific  disadvantaged  groups.  For  instance,  SAPTAGRAM,  the
Seven  Villages  Women’s  Self-Reliance  Movement,  has  22,000  members  spread  across  900
villages in three districts, focusing on continuing education for women.

Basic  literacy  programs  of  DNFE  are  delivered  via  two  main  modes,  the  center-based
14.
approach  (CBA)  and  the  total  literacy  movement  (TLM).  There  is  also  a  free  primer  distribution
program  channeled  through  philanthropic  voluntary  organizations.  CBA  programs  to  date  have
reached 4.7 million learners enrolled in 158,000 learning centers. The programs are delivered by
selected  NGOs,  contracted  by  DNFE.  More  than  450  NGOs  are  actively  involved  in  these
programs. TLM is carried out directly by DNFE. TLM programs have reached 9.3 million learners
enrolled  in  310,000  centers  to  date.  Under  TLM,  the  whole  community  is  mobilized  through
extensive  campaigns  to  achieve  full  literacy  in  a  district.  Under  the  deputy  commissioner  of  the
district,  a  TLM  association  is  formed,  involving  all  sectors  of  society  including  political  leaders.
DNFE  provides  technical  services  support  and  primers,  and  sends  monitoring  and  fact-finding
teams  to  each  district  and  subdistricts  (Upazilas).10  Teachers  are  locally  recruited,  educated,
unemployed men and women who receive a monthly honorarium (currently equivalent to $10).

15.
The first NFE project started in 1991 with significant external assistance, which provided 80
percent of the project cost. Subsequently, the Government’s share in the funding of NFE projects
increased steadily and TLM is entirely funded by the Government. The Government’s funding for
NFE comes from its development budget, with the exception of the salaries of civil servants. Of the
total  funding  of  over  $333  million  for  all  NFE  projects  –  completed,  current,  and  approved  up  to
March  2001  –  the  Government  provided  $167  million  (50  percent),  with  $91  million  (26  percent)
coming  from  aid  agency  loans  and  $75  million  (23  percent)  from  aid  agency  grants.  The
Government’s  allocation  of  funding  for  NFE,  as  a  percent  of  the  total  education  budget  and  as  a
percent  of  GDP,  has  increased  steadily  over  the  last  six  years.  The  cost  per  learner  on  NFE

neo-literates can acquire functional knowledge and skills as well as literacy. Completion of a basic

education  system  that  provides  follow-on  post-literacy  and  other  services  to  help  learners  retain,

18.
The  required  policy  framework  and  long-term  vision  also  need  to  reflect  up-to-date
conceptual  approaches  for  NFE  beyond  the  current  focus  of  the  Government  on  mainly
quantitative  target  achievement.  The  development  debate  about  literacy  has  undergone  major
changes and paradigmatic shifts during the last three decades. Increasingly, illiteracy is being seen
as  a  structural  social  problem  of  society  instead  of  being  a  social  pathology  and  an  individual
responsibility. At the same time, literacy is not a panacea for social development and change, but
more  a  prerequisite  for  such  development  and  change.  It  is  therefore  in  the  context  of  broader
educational  and  socioeconomic  development  when  interventions  focus  on  promoting  learner
involvement in civil society, economic activities, and activities designed to improve living standards.
The new understanding of literacy goes beyond the narrow definition of the three “Rs” – reading,
writing, and arithmetic. Literacy is defined as having skills to acquire information and skills that can
immediately  be  used  to  improve  living  standards  and  generate  income.  To  achieve  these  goals,
literacy programs need to respond to individual learner’s needs through flexible provisions.

PLCE, which combines further literacy development, or post-literacy with community- based
19.
skills training building on previous courses of basic literacy, requires a systemic approach. It needs
to integrate different types of training as well as contributions from a variety of stakeholders in the
context of decentralized implementation. Taking into account its limited resources, DNFE will need
to reallocate capacities currently used for directly implementing NFE programs and concentrate on
policy  planning,  information  analysis,  standard  setting,  contract  management,  M&E,  and  overall
system development. Based on a shared vision of NFE, a PLCE system needs to be based on a
national  framework  and  a  long-term  plan,  which  overcomes  the  campaign  and  singular  project
approach of the past. New delivery modes that respond to the diversity of skill requirements with
well-targeted  curricula  need  to  be  used.  The  traditional  teaching  role  must  become  one  of
facilitation,  and  facilitator  training  must  focus  on  the  demands  of  individual  learners  and
communities instead of  being  centered on schoolmasterish teaching and the provision of training
as part of a supply-side policy.

b. 

Quality and Relevance

21. While Bangladesh has had undeniable success in providing access to NFE, the quality of
the  offerings  still  require  substantial  improvement  if  functional  literacy  is  to  be  achieved  and
sustained. Facing the massive problem of illiteracy in the early 1990s, the Government adopted a
campaign  approach  (TLM)  and  the  CBA  approach  to  literacy  training.  Both  entailed  providing
learners with a crash program of basic reading and writing together with some “life skills training.”
These approaches were appropriate at the time, but there is a danger that neo-literates will slide
back  into  illiteracy  if  learning  is  not  reinforced.  Also,  basic  literacy  courses  did  not  include  skills
training  that  would  lead  trainees  to  better  income-earning  opportunities.  The  Government  has
adopted  a  concept  of  literacy  that  uses  the  traditional  ‘threshold’  measure  of  literacy.  This  views
literacy as a discrete characteristic that individuals either possess or do not possess. People are
described as being functionally literate11 if they have participated in a basic literacy program of the
Government. Such an understanding of literacy is useful where policy makers need a short-term,
readily  identifiable  goal  to  aim  for  and  particularly  where  literacy  is  being  introduced  for  the  first
time as was the case in Bangladesh several years ago. However, such a measure is not accurate
or sophisticated in defining the quality of achievement required and in identifying the literacy needs
of the poor in a diverse social and economic environment. It can offer little illumination about what
skills  functional  literacy  involves  for  learners  and  those  teaching  them.  There  are  ways  of
expanding this functional approach. One is to move toward thinking in terms of a broad range of
skills rather than a single skill. Literacy is seen as a set of interrelated skills, communication skills,
life skills, and social skills. This broad definition is common in many contemporary views of literacy.

22.
In  Bangladesh,  the  new  concept  of  PLCE  comprises  both  literacy  and  life  skills  training
called  post-literacy  training,  and  occupational  skills  training,  which  has  been  called  continuing
education. It is intended to follow and build on previous basic literacy courses. However, the rapid
expansion  of  basic  literacy  programs  has  outrun  the  capacity  of  DNFE  to  focus  on  the  quality  of
curricula, materials, and training of trainers as well as to develop new PLCE programs. This raises
a number of critical issues: (i) a gap between basic literacy and continuing education has resulted
in  loss  of  literacy  skills  in  many  learners;  (ii)  raised  awareness  of  the  importance  of  acquiring
income-generating skills created in learners expectations that have not been met; (iii) lack of M&E
regarding  program  participation,  learning  achievement,  and  quality  of  inputs  makes  it  difficult  to
build  on  previous  and  current  basic  literacy  courses;  (iv)  lack  of  records  of  literacy  levels  and
standardization  of  results  hampers  setting  quality  benchmarks  for  PLCE;  (v)  cooperation  and
coordination between DNFE and other ministries involved in NFE has not been achieved, and (vi)

c. 

Institutional Capacity

24.
  Although DNFE has been able to achieve its targets on delivery of basic literacy programs,
its capacity to initiate, supervise, administer, and monitor NFE has been stretched to the maximum
by  these  ongoing  basic  literacy  projects  and  the  huge  number  of  17  million  learners.  The
Government has adopted a centralized system of planning, program formulation, and monitoring in
the management of NFE with a decentralized mode of implementation. DNFE is the largest NFE
provider  in  the  country.  It  requires  strengthening  in  core  competencies  such  as  policy  planning,
contract  and  subsector  management,  and  in  developing  coordination  mechanisms  with  other
Government  institutions  and  agencies  that  are  currently  involved  in  offering  a  variety  of  skills
training  to  unskilled  learners.  The  most  effective  tool  for  DNFE  to  keep  up  with  its  supervisory
function  is  M&E.  While  costs-per-learner  indicators  exist,  on  learning  achievements  and  other
impacts of various past and ongoing NFE projects and campaigns data are lacking.  M&E becomes
even more an issue once PLCE is regarded as an evolving concept, adjusting to new challenges
by changing delivery modes and considering a new time horizon for achieving its goals. Demand-
driven  interventions  –  building  on  existing  structures  or  programs,  taking  into  account  lessons
learned,  and  exploring  diversified  means  and  methods  –  require  management  structures  and
processes  that  permit  good  policy  access,  substantial  authority,  a  high  degree  of  professional
competence,  a  good  management  information  system  (MIS),  improved  planning,  monitoring  and
reporting  capacity,  and  new  linkages  of  cooperation  between  multiple  stakeholders,  service
providers, and actors in the NFE field.   

25.
DNFE’s  current  roster  lists  about  450  NGOs  of  varying  quality  that  are  eligible  for
implementing  NFE  courses.  About  210  NGOs  will  be  required  to  implement  PLCE  courses.  A
majority of them have been assessed to have the necessary management and human resources
capacities to implement such programs. The other NGOs require substantial staff development for
them  to  play  their  role  successfully  within  a  new  PLCE  framework.  Forming  consortia  between
more experienced and efficiently managed NGOs and smaller local NGOs could be instrumental in
helping the latter to learn on the job and grow professionally. Thus, a potential shortage of qualified
NGOs  could  be  avoided.  Forming  consortia  among  NGOs  could  also  help  overcome  the  existing
fragmentation  of  professional  knowledge,  which  is  particularly  felt  in  the  area  of  core  curricula,
teaching materials, and training of trainers.

Policy Dialogue

44.
Policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  has  focused  on  three  key  areas:  (i)  the  need  to
develop an appropriate policy framework and action plans; (ii) the need to improve the quality and
relevance of PLCE, and (iii) the need to build capacity for emerging roles in the context of public-
private partnership (PPP). A summary of the policy dialogue follows.

1.

Policy Framework and Action Plan

The Government recognizes the need for a national policy framework for NFE, in particular
45.
for PLCE, to implement NEP. The policy framework for PLCE should therefore include all potential
learners,  including  school  dropouts  who  have  not  participated  in  basic  literacy  programs.  The
PMED has agreed to develop a long-term action plan, including financial budgets, by the end of the
second year of project implementation, which will consider the issue of inclusiveness. Apart from
inclusiveness,  a  unified  PLCE  approach  based  on  experience  gained  in  ongoing  and  previous
projects is another key ingredient for the policy framework as PLCE is a relatively new form of NFE
in  Bangladesh.  A  major  challenge  for  the  Government  in  the  development  of  the  new  policy
framework is developing PLCE models that respond to the diverse needs of learners and flexible
training  modules  to  meet  these  diverse  needs.  The  approaches  involve  the  establishment  of
enhanced  PPP,  which  will  lead  to  a  better  coordinated  and  more  efficient  use  of  available
resources.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  use  the  specialized  services  of  the  private  consulting
sector in Bangladesh, which will supplement the input of other institutions – DNFE and NGOs – for
M&E  of  the  proposed  Project.  Another  crucial–and  debated–element  of  the  policy  framework  is
beneficiary  contribution  to  help  shoulder  the  increasing  costs  of  NFE.  Currently,  the  Government
provides basic literacy courses free of cost to recipients on the ground that poor people are unable
to pay. However, learners make real contributions in kind, both in terms of providing practical work
in  maintaining  NFE  centers  and  the  opportunity  cost  of  income  forgone.  The  latter  represents  a
major cost for participants many of whom live at subsistence level. It was agreed that contributions
in kind from beneficiaries and communities need to be further encouraged to reduce overall costs.
For this to occur, PLCE courses must meet the needs of the learners. The Government will review
this issue, and the envisaged action plan of DNFE will take into account community contributions in
kind.

 2.

Improving the Quality and Relevance of PLCE

13

 46.
 One of the central thrusts of the Project is to improve training through high-quality curricula
and  materials,  and  a  better  trained  teaching  force.  For  PLCE  programs,  the  quality  of  learner
facilitation,  curriculum  model,  content  and  delivery  become  the  most  critical  factor.  The
Government  has  followed  a  rigid  approach  of  three  months’  post-literacy  training  followed  by  six
months  of  continuing  education.  Such  an  approach  has  proved  to  be  an  obstacle  to  learners’
motivation  in  the  23  pilot  projects  financed  by  NORAD  and  Sida.  The  challenge  of  an  integrated
approach is to design and implement tailor-made vocational skills’ training that integrates literacy
skills  development  seamlessly.  Only  an  integrated  approach  can  overcome  the  problem  of
diminishing motivation. The pilot projects found that learner motivation was highly correlated with
the  promise  of  skills  training  and  the  perceived  subsequent  improvement  in  livelihoods.  Tapping
this  motivation  early  in  the  learning  cycle  by  allowing  individuals  and  small  groups  to  engage  in
skills training as soon as the basic minimum literacy requirement for engaging in that skill has been
achieved is crucial. The Government has agreed to try out a more flexible approach of combining
PLCE in the proposed Project as long as the proportion of one third post-literacy training and two
thirds  continuing  education  is  kept.    It  was  also  agreed  that  a  national  task  force  of  NGOs  and
training  specialists  will  prepare  curricula  and  material,  and  conduct  training  of  trainers.  This  will
effectively combine the best talents and resource persons of the country. The task force will review
curricula and materials every year. It is also accepted that the PLCE program must respond to the
needs  of  local  communities.  These  needs  will  be  identified  through  extensive  dialogue  with  the
communities and potential beneficiaries, via CMCs, and supported by comprehensive information
on income-generating opportunities.

47.

delivering PLCE. This entails monitoring of targets and the quality of courses in terms of learning

performance  monitoring,  indicates  the  Government  desire  to  improve  on  previous  projects.  For
example, under the NFEP-1, a tenfold increase in the planned number of learners in the course of
project implementation brought into focus the issue of learning achievement and program quality.
Quality of program delivery and content will also be influenced by gender- related factors. A tracer
study  of  the  same  project  showed  that  increased  participation  of  women  in  NFE  has  a  strong
impact on the social and economic condition of families. The Government recognizes the need for
greater  representation  of  women  in  planning,  delivering,  and  participating  in  PLCE  programs.  It
supports  the  development  of  gender  action  plans  and  is  committed  to  implementing  current
Government gender policies.

A.

Rationale

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

The  Government  recognizes  that  illiteracy  and  lack  of  life  skills  are  a  major  factor
50.
contributing  to  rural  poverty.    Illiterates  are  unable  to  participate  in  the  employment  opportunities
emerging from economic growth, cannot participate in civil society, and, still worse, perpetuate the
cycle  of  poverty  by  failing  to  provide  their  children  with  educational  opportunities.  Despite  recent
strong  performance  in  improving  access  to  basic  education  for  children,  millions  of  adults  either
missed  the  chance  to  attend  school  altogether  or  dropped  out  after  a  few  years  of  school  and
remain  functionally  illiterate.  Since  1991  the  Government  has  exerted  major  efforts  to  eradicate
illiteracy through several projects and the establishment of DNFE in 1995.  Since then DNFE has
funded  literacy  training  for  17  million  learners  mainly  through  community-supported  centers  and
with  the  assistance  of  NGOs.  Evaluations  of  DNFE  literacy  programs  show  that  learners  acquire
significant  new  skills  and  develop  more  progressive  social  attitudes,  e.g.,  greater  participation  in
economic  activities,  enhanced  ability  to  access  and  use  micro-credit,  more  active  participation  in
civil  society,  and  greater  propensity  to  send  their  children  to  school  and  to  regulate  their  fertility.
However,  the  neo-literate  graduates  of  these  early  programs  require  further  training  to  reinforce
their  new  skills  and  to  acquire  a  new  set  of  skills  aimed  at  improving  their  employability  and
breaking the cycle of poverty. Appropriate curricula and trained facilitators are required to train an
estimated  1.6  million  learners  and  thus  provide  opportunities  for  them  to  directly  apply  newly
acquired literacy skills, and prepare them for income-generating activities. The Project will support
and expand DNFE’s mandate to provide a comprehensive range of PLCE courses to neo-literates.
It will develop curricula and materials as well as train trainers to implement these courses.

51.
NGOs  of  various  sizes,  with  a  diversity  of  mandates,  funded  by  the  Government;  and
external  agencies  and  other  sources  have  successfully  conducted  a  variety  of  basic  literacy
programs  in  the  past.  Given  this  vast  though  organizationally  fragmented  experience  and
considering  limited  implementation  capacities,  the  Project  promotes  partnerships  among  private
sector  organizations  and  with  the  Government,  based  on  shared  objectives,  concepts,  and  joint
monitoring and implementation as part of a new policy framework and long-term vision for PLCE.
The  Project  encourages  consortia  between  leading  NGOs  and  smaller  NGOs  to  achieve
knowledge and technology transfer and capacity building. PLCE courses have to build on previous
basic  literacy  efforts  of  about  17  million  learners  in  Bangladesh.  The  political  duty  of  the
Government  to  provide  NFE  activities  evenly  throughout  the  country  with  limited  resources
necessitates coverage of 29 selected districts and 210 Upazilas, which will be targeted mainly on a
first completed (basic literacy) – first served (by PLCE) basis, complemented by learners who have
only recently completed a course. The PLCEHDP-1 of the Government follows the same rule for
the remaining 32 districts of the country, while three Chittagong Hill districts and urban Upazilas of
Dhaka and Chittagong are covered by special projects due to specific beneficiary needs.

 B.

Objective and Scope

15

52.
The Project’s long-term sector objective is to help reduce rural poverty through investments
in  human  development  aimed  at  empowering  the  rural  poor  by  providing  them  with  literacy,  life
skills, and income-generating skills. The Project aims to establish a community-based and needs-
oriented  PLCE  course  program  and  a  supporting  organizational  framework  for  1.6  million  neo-
literates in 29 districts.

53.
The Project will be implemented in a phased manner with a comprehensive review at the
end  of  the  second  year,  which  will  finally  determine  the  implementation  mechanisms  and  the
teaching  approach.  Preparing  teachers  and  curricula  before  implementing  courses  in  a  limited
number  of  Upazilas,  and  gradually  increasing  the  number  of  learners  while  continuously
strengthening monitoring, curricula and materials development, and training of trainers reflect the
quality focus of the project approach. Continuous feedback and evaluation of results will be used to
guide  the  project  throughout  implementation.  The  Project  will  promote  the  active  involvement  of
learners  and  communities  in  course  planning  and,  where  appropriate,  will  use  information  and
communication technology for efficient implementation. Developing and implementing new modes
for delivering PLCE will provide essential inputs for a national framework for NFE.  The Project’s
objectives  will  be  achieved  through  four  components:  (i)  policy  framework  development  for  NFE
based  on  decentralized  implementation  and  learners’  participation  in  planning;  (ii)  curricula  and
materials development and dissemination for PLCE programs to lay the groundwork for the Project
and  for  similar  future  activities;  (iii)  capacity  building  for  organizations  involved  in  project
implementation  and  strengthening  the  regulatory  and  supervisory  functions  of  Government;  (iv)
delivery  of  PLCE  courses  targeting  more  than  1.6  million  learners  who  will  participate  in  courses
organized by the Project in 29 districts of Bangladesh (Appendix 1). While the last two components
relate  to  the  210  Upazilas  where  the  Project  will  provide  services,  contributions  to  the  policy
framework and to curriculum development and training of trainers will be sector-wide. Details of the
project components are described as follows.

1.

Policy Framework Development (Component 1)

54.
This  component  aims  to  develop  a  policy  framework  conducive  to  a  flexible,  responsive,
and sustainable program of PLCE.  The Project will provide technical expertise and opportunities
for public and private stakeholders to collaborate in contributing to a policy framework, which will
be part of a long-term vision for PLCE. It will be based on the Government’s Sixth Five-Year-Plan
(2002–2007) and on foundation work done by the PLCEHDP-1, which has the lead in developing a
national  framework  with  the  goal  of  strengthening  the  NFE  subsector  of  education.  The  project
contributions  to  PLCE  will  focus  on  organizational  –  including  development  of  regulations  –
management,  and  implementation  arrangements  conducive  to  a  new  concept  of  PLCE  based  on
increased  PPP.  PLCE  can  only  be  successful  if  it  becomes  a  long-term  and  joint  undertaking  of
learners,  civil  society,  private  sector  organizations,  and  the  Government.  Ultimately,  this
partnership  may  lead  to  sharing  of  costs  by  the  private  sector  and  beneficiaries.  In  a  continuing
and evolving process, the Project will demonstrate how PLCE needs to be implemented so as to
support  national  objectives  like  education  for  all,  the  goal  of  poverty  reduction,  and  objectives  of
NFE  as  stipulated  by  the  NEP.  In  particular,  linkages  and  the  division  of  work  between  actors  of
public  agencies,  NGOs,  private  sector  organizations,  and  community-based  organizations  like
CMCs will be strengthened based on the principle of PPP. The institutional setting of PLCE will be
supported  by  the  elaboration  of  appropriate  rules  and  regulations  that  define  coordination
mechanisms, financial contributions, as well as tasks and responsibilities of PLCE stakeholders at
national, district, Upazila, and community levels. The Project will provide expertise to work out in
detail a pedagogical concept of PLCE that integrates PLCE in a manner that motivates learners to
regularly  attend  courses.  The  Project  will  also  support  impact  evaluation  studies  providing
feedback  for  further  adjustment  of  the  chosen  PLCE  concept,  and  on  the  extent  of  poverty
reduction.    In  addition  to  the  clear  articulation  of  the  PLCE  concept,  the  definition  of  tools  and

mechanisms  for  quality  assurance  will  constitute  an  important  element  of  the  framework.  Annual
planning  workshops  as  well  as  Project-related  coordination  meetings  at  district,  Upazila,  and

2.

Development, Dissemination, and Adaptation of Curricula for PLCE Programs
(Component 2)

55.
The purpose of this component 2 is to establish and test a wide range of core curricula to
be used by INGOs for PLCE courses. At the community level, such core curricula will need to be
complemented to varying degrees by facilitators (teachers) so as to guarantee meaningfulness for
learners  and  responsiveness  to  local  conditions.  The  demand-based  approach  to  the  delivery  of
PLCE  services  requires  INGOs  to  conduct  an  income-generating-opportunity  survey,  which  will
allow  learners  to  make  informed  decisions  about  the  kind  of  skills  training  they  want  considering
their choice from a range of proposed trades for a specific area. This survey will explore new skills
and  emerging  opportunities  for  income  generation,  including  higher  yielding  occupations  for
women.  Thus  the  selected  approach  to  curricula  development  combines  the  advantages  of  the
development and mass replication of standardized core curricula at the national level with tailoring
courses  to  specific  local  conditions  and  to  specific  groups  of  learners.  The  achieved  flexibility  is
essential, given the consensus that neo-literates continue to use and improve their skills only when
there is an economic or social incentive to do so.

56.
The PLCE system as envisaged by the Project will require the development of curricula and
learning materials that cover a diversity of income-enhancing activities as well as training of master
trainers  to  make  them  familiar  with  a  new,  learner-centered  approach  to  NFE.  To  overcome  the
existing  fragmentation  of  specialized  professional  resources  in  the  country,  the  Project  will  invite
proposals  from  both  NGOs  and  private  consulting  companies  to  form  a  national  task  force  for
curriculum and  material development and training of trainers. The task force will collect, analyze,
and review existing curricula and materials. It is expected that the big national NGOs will volunteer
to contribute to curriculum and materials development without being contracted. Curricula writers’
workshops will gather the country’s best resource persons for developing the core curricula based
on a modular approach. Such curricula will allow flexible use according to learners’ needs and local
requirements.  The  curricula  will  contain  assessment  formats  and  tests  to  measure  learning
achievement. Emphasis will be on trades related to local wage employment, self-employment, and
other  income-generating  activities  demanded  by  learners  and  informed  by  surveys.  Demanded
topics like health, nutrition, and family planning as well as modules on literacy and numeracy skills
will serve the objective of allowing learners to become more confident in taking their life into their
own hands and participate more actively in activities of their community.

57.
The  Project  will  provide  international  and  local  assistance  for  curriculum  developers  to
employ a method for analyzing occupational competencies related to certain trades and to develop
competency-based approaches for assessing learning achievement, which will allow monitoring of
outcomes  and  a  subsequent  review  and  modification  of  curricula.  Each  trade  will  have  its  own
training  manual  –  leaving  space  for  local  inputs  and  specifics  to  be  introduced  by  implementing
partner  agencies  and  facilitators  for  specific  courses.  The  teaching  manuals,  where  possible,  will
integrate  literacy,  occupational,  and  life  skills.  PMED  will  approve  the  final  curricula  before  mass
replication  and  nationwide  dissemination  and  has  therefore  to  retain  and  improve  the  quality  of
DNFE’s limited technical manpower. The task force will also, where possible, use the Internet for
disseminating  course  information  and  materials.  This  will  allow  the  making  of  printouts  at  district
and Upazila levels by district coordinators (DCOs), monitoring associates (MAs) and Upazila-based
program  coordinators  (PCs).  In  addition  to  being  responsible  for  curriculum  development,  the
members of the task force will serve as core trainers who will train at least two master trainers of
each INGO. Applying a cascade approach, altogether 840 master trainers will then be able to train
16,800 facilitators (Appendix 4). All activities of the task force will imply compiling and using past

for  their  choices.  In  addition,  participation  has  an  educational  dimension,  and  it  is  vital  that  it  be
considered  as  a  form  of  collective  learning.  Building  capacity  among  the  poor  requires  their  full
involvement in the PLCE program.

59.
DNFE  has  the  national  mandate  for  coordinating  Government-funded  NFE  and  ensuring
political, financial, and administrative compliance with set Government standards. By implementing
the Project, the Government will be supported to achieve its aim of “decentralization for program
planning,  strategy  formulation  and  resource  formulation  and  encouraging  local  level  participation
with ownership in planning and implementation” as stated in the current five-year plan. The Project
will support DNFE in assuming a role in the direction of more policy planning, information analysis,
contract management, standard setting, and system evaluation. It will help DNFE to improve target
monitoring and to develop a stronger concern for program quality. The Project supports setting up
quality standards, which reflect diversity, creativity, and responsiveness to varying circumstances
and the importance of complementarity and collaboration among actors involved in implementing
PLCE.    Approving  quality  standards  of  the  core  curricula  for  continuing  education  and  teacher
training, and assessing curriculum implementation need to remain the responsibility of DNFE at the
national level. The Project will therefore support further development of specialized expertise within
DNFE  through  training.  All  Government  ministries  have  a  provision  for  a  women-in-development
(WID) focal point — an officer with the rank of joint secretary/joint chief. The current joint secretary
of PMED is designated as the WID focal point assisted by an associate WID focal point with the
rank of senior assistant chief. DNFE has a sub-WID focal point with the rank of deputy director. A
specialized  international  consultant  will  work  closely  with  these  officers  to  strengthen  DNFE’s
capacity in addressing poverty and equity issues in the Project and the subsector.

Implementing PLCE Programs (Component 4)

Under this component an estimated 1.6 million learners will complete PLCE courses offered
62.
by  210  selected  INGOs  who  are  accountable  to  communities  and  learners  by  obligation  and
choice.  The  contract  packages  of  INGOs  will  include  the  purchase  of  skills  training  kits  for  all
learners, motorcycles for project staff, and teaching aids for facilitators.   Up to 29 MOPAs will be
selected to monitor implementation quality in each of the 29 districts. The plan is to provide training
for  at  least  nine  months  of  each  year,  divided  into  one  third  of  post-literacy  and  two  thirds  of
continuing  education  on  the  average.  The  remaining  three  months  will  cover  harvest  periods,
periods of adverse weather conditions, and time for family issues of the learners. The three months
will  also  be  used  for  performance  assessment,  teacher  training,  and  updated  surveys  of  income-
generating opportunities surveys and INGOs’ preparation of action plans for the following year. In
the nine months of training, courses will be of varying length to suit learners’ needs and choices. It
is envisaged that more than one course will be provided in a nine-month period at the same center.

63.
INGOs in cooperation with CMCs to be physically established and equipped by the Project
will  compile  an  inventory  of  available  training  sites  in  each  community.  It  is  assumed  that  each

centers  (CECs)  will  be  required  in  each  community.  INGOs  will  develop  a  rental  plan  for  these
facilities. Implementation of PLCE programs will be supported by substantial external expertise in
the field of PLCE, monitoring, and social development. The Project will support DNFE in contract
management, supervision, and quality assurance of programs.

64.

communities. PLCE courses will usually be two hours a day and up to six days a week, integrating
post-literacy and skills training. There will be separate courses for males and for female learners.
Locally hired resource persons, guided and advised by facilitators of INGOs, will be responsible for
the  trade-related  skills  training.  Standardized  course  achievement  tests,  developed  by  the  task
force, will help to monitor learning achievement and provide feedback to curriculum developers for
improving curricula and materials. Continuous qualitative program monitoring by MOPAs will give

 feed-back  for  program  development  and  refresher  training  for  facilitators.  Quantitative  monitoring
by PCs and MAs will provide inputs for the MIS of DNFE.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Economic and Financial Analyses

1.

Economic Justification

The Project is justified on both efficiency and equity grounds. Continuing education training
101.
in  Bangladesh,  especially  in  the  rural  areas,  either  is  absent  or  is  undersupplied  because  the
private sector cannot provide and finance them. The Project will remedy this economic inefficiency
by  giving  neo-literate  men  and  women  the  skills  needed  for  employment  or  income  generation
based  on  local  opportunities.  The  Project  will  help  improve  agricultural  productivity  by  increasing
the skills of farm families and will support self-employment by linking existing microcredit facilities
with  skills  training.  In  the  long  term,  employers  will  have  access  to  more  skilled,  literate,  and
productive  employees  better  able  to  contribute  to  economic  growth.  On  the  other  hand,  while
Bangladesh  has  achieved  successful  economic  growth  in  recent  years,  such  growth  has  not
proportionately benefited the poor, as reflected in the steadily widening inequality in the distribution
of incomes. The Project addresses an area of endemic poverty by focusing on the poor who have
completed courses in basic literacy.

102.
The Project aims at enhancing the human and social capital of the direct beneficiaries. It is
envisaged  that  at  least  50  percent  of  the  beneficiaries  will  be  women,  for  whom  income-earning
opportunities have been very limited. The Project will promote female participation in economic and
income-generating  activities  of  households  in  the  rural  sector.  Research  studies  in  various
developing countries have demonstrated that with each level of education and training, women are
more  likely  to  have  lower  fertility  rates,  smaller  family  sizes,  better  child-rearing  practices,  better
health-related practices, more work outside the home, higher incomes, and, most crucial of all, will
pass on to their children strongly pro-education, pro-training, and pro-literacy values.

The  Project  also  contributes  to  an  enabling  institutional  environment  for  NFE.  At  the  sub-
103.
sector level, the Project will support the development of a national system of continuing education
that  will meet the  needs  of the country and will upgrade its workforce to meet national economic
goals. DNFE, which has the national mandate for coordinating and expanding continuing education

Economic Analysis

104.
The Project represents an innovative attempt to address one of the main causes of poverty,
especially among women, by focusing on the achievement of functional literacy and the acquisition
of practical, employable skills. Without the Project, the potential beneficiaries will continue to work
on an unskilled, inefficient, and low productivity basis. The project impact will put them on the path
toward higher incomes through involvement in microenterprises, self-employment, and other work.
The enhanced literacy and income-related skills will be a significant factor in breaking the cycle of
poverty in the rural areas of Bangladesh for 1.6 million learners. The economic argument for NFE
is stronger if existing premises and facilities can be used at little or no cost.

The  Project’s  internal  rate  of  return  (IRR)  under  a  set  of  conservative  assumptions  is

estimated  to  be  35.3  percent.  The  sensitivity  of  Project  viability  was  tested  under  some  adverse

Financial Sustainability

106. While  the  Government  is  expected  to  be  the  primary  source  of  funds  for  the  removal  of
barriers to literacy and NFE, it is inappropriate for the Government to continue to fully finance the
comprehensive  system.  The  use  of  existing  infrastructure  for  training  will  greatly  reduce  NFE
system costs. Supplementary payments to available teachers in the formal system will encourage
them to function, at small cost, as trained teachers for PLCE courses. The use of rental facilities
will  reduce  capital  costs.  It  is  envisaged  that  skills  trainers  will  be  local  trades  people  hired  and
trained for a few hours of training work each day, at the commercial hourly rate for artisans.

107. Notwithstanding  the  various  considerations  that  will  contribute  to  cost  reduction,  it  is

assumption  that  the  economic  growth  rate,  share  of  education  expenditure  share  in  GDP,  and

peak  of  the  project  recurrent  expenditure  in  2005-2006,  its  share  in  the  NFE  expenditure  will  be
about 28 percent, and then decline to 21.5 percent at the end of the implementation period. Since
the present DNFE programs consisting of basic literacy and post-literacy courses will largely have

depend  on  whether  similar  investments  will  be  made  and  in  what  size  in  the  NFE  sector;  that,
however, is outside the scope of the analysis here.

GENDER ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY

A.

Gender Issues in Nonformal Education

1.
The  Government  of  Bangladesh  is  one  of  the  countries  with  a  separate  Ministry  of
Women and Children Affairs (MOWCA), the lead government agency for women’s development.
All sectors and ministries also have provision for a women-in-development (WID) focal point –
with  the  rank  of  joint  secretary/joint  chief  1  and  a  National  Council  for  Women’s  Development
chaired  by  the  Prime  Minister.  MOWCA  also  has  Women’s  Affairs’  officers  at  district  and
subdistrict  levels.  However,  MOWCA  lacks  an  explicit  and  well-resourced  mandate  for  taking
the leadership role that is needed to prioritize gender issues across ministries and departments.
WID focal points lack terms of reference or adequate earmarked resources for the dual role they
often  play  and  are  supplemented  by  junior  assistant  and  sub-WID  focal  points  who  are
marginalized  within  their  line  departments.  The  joint  secretary  of  the  Primary  and  Mass
Education  Division  (PMED)  acts  as  the  WID  focal  point  and  is  assisted  by  an  associate  WID
officer  with  the  rank  of  senior  associate  chief  in  PMED.  A  sub-WID  focal  point  within  the
Research and Documentation Unit of the Diretorate of Nonformal Education (DNFE) is charged
with assisting the WID officers.2 Within DNFE, however, there is little awareness of this role, its
potential, or what is needed to make it effective.

2.
The  Government  approved  a  national  action  plan  (NAP)  for  women’s  advancement  in
1997. This plan foresees the  increase in number of female officers at all levels, particularly at
the  decision-making  and  management  levels  in  both  ministries  charged  with  education  in
Bangladesh  (Ministry  of  Education  and  PMED).  Budget  allocations  for  women  and  girls  in
specific educational programs and projects are part of the plan. Action 14 of the plan envisages
the  strengthening  of  adult  education  programs  for  women  in  various  fields  through  nonformal
education (NFE). Activities to be undertaken under the plan are (i) assessing women’s needs for
learning;  (ii)  reviewing  curricula,  methods,  and  education  materials  of  existing  programs  and
modifying them to fulfill the needs of women and to increase the areas and coverage and; (iii)
incorporating  gender  relations,  legal  literacy,  human  rights,  health  care  and  other  important
issues in the program. DNFE is vested with primary responsibility for implementing this part of
the plan.

The  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s)  partnership  agreement  on  poverty  reduction
3.
with  the  Government  of  Bangladesh  stresses  its  assistance  in  the  social  sectors,  targeted  at
reducing  human  poverty  with  particular  emphasis  on  women,  specifically  mentions  projects  in
NFE. ADB’s gender strategy for Bangladesh includes supporting women’s access to resources
and services and promoting women’s employment and income generation (footnote 1).

4.
With  education  receiving  a  high  proportion  of  total  expenditure  for  the  social  sector,  a
considerable increase in female enrollment at the primary school level has been achieved. The
gender gap at this level decreased from 22 percent in 1985 to 3 percent over the past 15 years.
Progress  at  the  secondary  education  level  has  been  slow  and  female  drop-out  rates  are
alarmingly  high.  However,  the  Government’s  emphasis  on  girls’  education  and  specific
programs for eradicating female illiteracy are encouraging more gender equity.

5.

seriously affected by sociocultural values, norms, and traditions. Preference for male children is
an obvious cultural trait in Bangladesh as it is in other South Asian countries. Parents believe
that investment in a son’s education yields a higher return since the boy is socially expected to
look them when they are old. Girls are perceived as homemakers, and rural parents emphasize
teaching girls the basic skills for efficient performance of the domestic role. The prevalence of

Inclusiveness in Nonformal Education

9.
Results of the 23 pilot projects on post-literacy and continuing education (PLCE) suggest
that there is a tendency to favor young, unmarried girls when selecting course participants from
eligible  TLM  and  CBA  graduates.  Consequently,  older  and  poorer  women  who  may  be
burdened with children are passed over. This appears to be justified as long-term benefits from
the  program  and  employment  opportunities  are  higher  for  younger  woman.  Younger  people
generally tend to learn faster than older learners, have more energy and less demands on their
time. Many of these girls though intellectually capable have never gone to school.

10.
However,  if  focus  is  on  those  most  in  need  and  on  the  poorest  and  least  advantaged
people,  older  women  would  be  a  key  target  group.    Changes  in  their  lives  and  economic
situation will affect many people within their families.  They also carry more weight in terms of
changing  attitudes  and  tradition  of  family  members  and  their  immediate  environment.  This
suggests that a wider concept of inclusiveness may include the provision of child care, allowing
mothers  to  participate  in  PLCE  courses  and  generate  income  for  female  caretakers  in  the
village.

A  large  proportion  of  NGOs  are  concentrating  on  women’s  issues.  NGOs  have  had  a
considerable  impact  on  women’s  development  in  the  fields  of  NFE,  health,  and  social
awareness. NGOs have contributed by “insistence on the participatory process of development
(planning, decision making, implementation, monitoring, evaluation) (as this) empowers women
by dramatically highlighting their inclusion in all phases of a project. It also builds their capacity
and  skill  in  public  participation  and  management”  (footnote  1).  The  Project’s  approach  in
implementing  PLCE  courses  through  NGOs  should  therefore  have  a  positive  impact  on  the

The economic rationale for the Project derives from both economic efficiency and equity.
The efficiency issue arises from the fact that continuing education and training in Bangladesh,
especially in rural areas, is either absent or under-supplied. The argument for a proactive role
for  public  interventions  is  that  while  basic-level  continuing  education  and  training  activities  are
mostly  in  the  nature  of  public  goods  and  have  large  externalities,  they  are  characterized  by
uncertainty  and  incomplete  information,  leading  to  a  poor  supply  response  from  the  private
sector.

2.
The equity issue arises from the equitable provision of “merit wants” to reduce poverty. While
Bangladesh  has  achieved  successful  economic  growth  in  recent  years,  such  growth  has  not
benefited the poor, due to the wide and steadily widening inequality in the distribution of incomes.
The  unskilled  poor  living  in  rural  areas,  and  especially  the  women,  do  not  have  sufficient  human
capital  to  benefit  from  the  opportunities  created  by  the  country’s  gradual  process  of  economic
modernization. The Project will assist the Government in reducing poverty by improving the literacy
and income-related skills of the rural poor.

addition, a greater percentage of graduates are sending their children to school, participating in

various adverse scenarios. Three scenarios were prepared. First, under the low-wage scenario

E.

Financial Sustainability

9.
To  ensure  financial  sustainability  of  the  project  activities,  the  Government  and
communities  or  beneficiaries  must  be  able  to  provide  and  allocate  the  necessary  recurrent
costs.  The existing evidence may be summarized as follows: (i) regarding costs falling on the
Government, the Government has for some years demonstrated its commitment to funding NFE
by  steadily  increasing  year  by  year  the  proportion  of  the  total  education  budget  allocated  to
NFE;  (ii)  communities  at  subdistrict  and  village  levels  have  demonstrated  their  willingness  to
contribute in kind to the success of education and training activities by working to renovate and
upgrade  existing  facilities  and  by  providing  some  of  the  resources,  e.g.  sitting  mats;  and  (iii)
regarding  cost  recovery  from  beneficiaries,  there  is  evidence  that  participants  in  continuing
education activities are prepared to contribute to the cost of training activities that they perceive
as directly related to income-enhancing possibilities. In one pilot under the Project’s first phase,
it would be desirable to test out partial cost recovery with funds managed at the village level and
used  to  purchase  training  independently.  This  would  be  carried  out  after  careful  analysis  of
options based on similar attempts in Bangladesh. Apart from training, another possibility might
be to encourage the start of a group savings scheme within an established continuing education
center that would raise money to purchase, from the private sector, microenterprise marketing
and business development support services.
